questions.question: A completely excised skin lesion of the face proved to be a basal cell carcinoma. The further management of the case should be:
questions.explanation: BCC rarely metastasizes. Complete excision is curative, but regular follow-up is needed to monitor for recurrence or new lesions.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common site of Kaposi's sarcoma in the head and neck is:
questions.explanation: Kaposi's sarcoma, often associated with HIV/AIDS, most frequently manifests intraorally on the hard and soft palate.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Following traumatic peripheral nerve transection, regrowth usually occurs at which of the following rates?
questions.explanation: Axonal regeneration in peripheral nerves typically occurs at a rate of approximately 1 mm per day (or about 1 inch per month) after the initial delay period.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Haemangioma of the face in children:
options: Should be resected in the newborn period
Should be resected only if it persists 10 years of age
Will involute by 3 years of age in most children
Can be treated by laser ablation
questions.explanation: Laser ablation is a valid treatment for superficial lesions or complications. Most involute spontaneously.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In a patient with head trauma, compression of the oculomotor nerve (resulting in a dilated pupil) is produced by:
options: Herniation of the uncal process of the temporal lobe
Laceration of the corpus callosum by the falx cerebri
Occult damage to the superior cervical ganglion
questions.explanation: Transtentorial (uncal) herniation compresses the ipsilateral oculomotor nerve (CN III) against the tentorium cerebelli, causing pupillary dilation (Hutchinson's pupil).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Le Fort II fracture entails injuries to all of the following EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Le Fort fractures involve the maxilla. The mandible is a separate bone and not part of the Le Fort classification.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common initial manifestation of increasing intracranial pressure in the victim of head trauma is:
questions.explanation: A change in the level of consciousness (e.g., confusion, drowsiness) is the most sensitive and earliest sign of rising intracranial pressure.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following are level III lymph nodes of the neck?
questions.explanation: Level III lymph nodes refer to the middle jugular group, located between the carotid bifurcation (or hyoid bone) superiorly and the omohyoid muscle (or cricoid cartilage) inferiorly.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is/are not associated with increased likelihood of infection after major elective surgery?
options: Infection at a remote body site
questions.explanation: Controlled diabetes poses significantly lower risk than uncontrolled diabetes. Malnutrition and steroids are stronger predictors.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Branchial cyst commonly arises from remnant of:
questions.explanation: The vast majority (approx. 95%) of branchial anomalies (cysts, sinuses, fistulas) arise from the remnants of the Second Branchial Arch/Cleft.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 9-year-old boy has a translucent swelling in the left supraclavicular region, diagnosed as cystic hygroma. What is true of cystic hygroma?
options: It arises from sweat glands in the neck
It is usually an anterior midline structure
It may occur in the mediastinum
Its lesions are usually easy to enucleate
questions.explanation: Cystic hygroma (lymphangioma) can extend into the mediastinum (axillary or cervical extension). It is not premalignant, not midline, and is often difficult to enucleate completely due to infiltration.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The commonest discrete lump of the parotid gland is:
options: Tuberculosis of the parotid lymph node
questions.explanation: Pleomorphic adenoma (benign mixed tumor) is the most common tumor of the parotid gland, accounting for about 80% of benign parotid neoplasms.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The treatment of submandibular calculus lying within the duct is to:
options: Remove the stone by making an opening in the duct
Slit opens the duct at the papilla
questions.explanation: For stones palpable in the duct (anteriorly), the treatment is sialodochotomy (making an incision in the duct to remove the stone) via an intraoral approach.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The potato tumor of the neck is:
questions.explanation: "Potato tumor" is a classic colloquial description for a Carotid Body Tumor (Chemodectoma) due to its firm, rubbery consistency and shape.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is brilliantly translucent?
questions.explanation: Cystic hygroma is filled with clear lymph fluid and is characteristically brilliantly translucent on transillumination.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which is the most appropriate form of biopsy for a major salivary gland tumour?
options: Open surgical biopsy to allow histology
questions.explanation: FNAC is the gold standard for preoperative diagnosis. Open biopsy is contraindicated due to the risk of tumor seeding and fistula formation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following structures is not an anatomical relation to the submandibular salivary gland?
questions.explanation: The inferior alveolar nerve runs in the mandibular canal, not relating to the gland. Facial vessels and Lingual/Hypoglossal nerves are relations.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Cystic hygroma is a:
questions.explanation: Cystic hygroma is a congenital malformation of the lymphatic system, technically known as a macrocystic lymphangioma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The term plunging ranula refers to which clinical entity?
options: Mucous retention cyst from sublingual glands limited by mylohyoid
Mucous retention cyst from sublingual glands perforating mylohyoid to enter neck
Midline neck mass moving on tongue protrusion
questions.explanation: A plunging ranula herniates through the mylohyoid muscle, appearing as a neck swelling.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 24-year-old female presents with a neck swelling on the left side, located in the carotid triangle deep to the sternomastoid. It is opaque on trans-illumination. Aspiration reveals mucoid fluid rich in cholesterol crystals. Diagnosis:
questions.explanation: A swelling deep to the sternocleidomastoid containing cholesterol crystals is the classic presentation of a Branchial Cyst.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 58-year-old woman undergoes excision biopsy of a tumor in the left posterior triangle of her neck. Histology suggests metastatic cancer. What is the most likely site of the primary tumor?
questions.explanation: A left supraclavicular/posterior triangle lymph node (Virchow's node) enlargement is classically associated with abdominal malignancies, particularly gastric carcinoma (Stomach).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 40-year-old woman is suspected of having a carotid body tumor. Which one of the following is most characteristic of such a tumor?
options: It is more common at sea level
It arises from structures that respond to changes in blood volume
It arises from the structures that respond to changes in PO2
questions.explanation: Carotid body tumors (Chemodectomas) arise from chemoreceptor cells (glomus cells) at the carotid bifurcation that monitor blood oxygen levels (PO2).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 59-year-old woman has carcinoma of the posterior third of her tongue. What is true about this condition?
options: Lymph gland spread is often encountered
The recurrent laryngeal nerve is infiltrated
questions.explanation: Tumors of the posterior third of the tongue have a rich lymphatic drainage and often present with early lymph node metastasis, leading to a poorer prognosis compared to anterior tumors.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The commonest site for lip cancer is:
options: Lower lip at junction of middle, outer thirds
Upper lip at junction of middle, outer thirds
questions.explanation: Lip cancer (Squamous Cell Carcinoma) most commonly affects the lower lip, typically at the vermilion border between the middle and outer thirds.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common salivary tumor is:
questions.explanation: Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor affecting the salivary glands, particularly the parotid.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which structure attaches the deep lobe of the submandibular gland to the lingual nerve?
questions.explanation: The submandibular ganglion suspends the submandibular gland from the lingual nerve.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The commonest swellings in the carotid triangle are:
questions.explanation: Enlarged lymph nodes (Lymphadenopathy) are the most common cause of neck swellings in the carotid triangle and the neck overall.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 33-year-old female noted a discharge from a sinus below the right angle of the mandible. She recalls previous episodes of fullness/pain. What is the most likely cause?
questions.explanation: A sinus at the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid (near the angle of the mandible) with a history of recurrent infection is characteristic of a Branchial Fistula/Cyst (Second cleft anomaly).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 43-year-old teacher underwent left parotidectomy. Post-op, paralysis of the left lower lip was observed. This is due to injury to:
questions.explanation: Cervical branch injury can cause lower lip weakness due to loss of Platysma function. (Marginal Mandibular is classic, but Cervical is the key here).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 5-year-old girl presents with difficulty breathing. A 3-cm mass is found in the midline on the posterior aspect of the tongue. Diagnosis:
options: Foreign body stuck to the tongue
questions.explanation: A midline mass at the base of the tongue (foramen cecum area) in a child is highly suggestive of a Lingual Thyroid (failed descent of the thyroid gland).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A patient has malignant metastasis in right upper deep cervical lymph nodes. No symptoms of primary. The possible primary lesion may be any of the following, EXCEPT:
options: Carcinoma of pyriform fossa of hypopharynx
questions.explanation: Laryngeal carcinoma usually presents early with hoarseness. Others are notorious for occult presentation.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About adenolymphoma (Warthin's tumor), all the following statements are true, EXCEPT:
options: The tumour is related to smoking
It has epithelial and lymphoid components
Facial nerve palsy is characteristic of this tumour
questions.explanation: Adenolymphoma is a benign tumor. Facial nerve palsy is a sign of malignancy and nerve infiltration, which does not occur with benign Warthin's tumors.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About branchial cyst and fistula, all are true, EXCEPT:
options: A branchial cyst is observed in the neonate
A branchial fistula is present at birth
A branchial cyst is partially covered by the sternomastoid muscle
The main differential diagnosis of branchial cyst is cold abscess
A branchial cyst contains cholesterol crystals
questions.explanation: Branchial cysts typically present in young adulthood (2nd/3rd decade), not in neonates. Branchial *fistulas*, however, are present at birth.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About cold abscess of the neck, all the following statements are true, EXCEPT:
options: It is usually caused by caseation of tuberculous lymphadenitis
The abscess may have two components, one superficial, and one deep to the deep fascia
The condition is mildly painful with low-grade fever
Anti-tuberculous treatment is an essential part of treatment
questions.explanation: Cold abscesses should NOT be incised as this leads to chronic discharging sinuses. Treatment involves aspiration and anti-tuberculous chemotherapy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About Ludwig's angina, all the following statements are true, EXCEPT:
options: This is tuberculous infection of the deep neck spaces
Diabetics are more prone to develop this condition
Oedema of the floor of mouth pushes the tongue upwards
Urgent incision and drainage is needed
questions.explanation: Ludwig's angina is an acute bacterial (usually Streptococcal/Staphylococcal) cellulitis of the floor of the mouth, not a tuberculous infection.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About submandibular salivary stones, all the following statements are true EXCEPT:
options: A stone can be detected by CT scan
A stone may present by a submandibular swelling that increases in size by eating
A submandibular salivary swelling can be rolled over the angle of the mandible
A stone in the gland is treated by submandibular sialadenectomy
questions.explanation: Submandibular swellings do not 'roll over the angle of the mandible'. That sign is characteristic of parotid tail tumors.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About thoracic outlet syndrome, all statements are true, EXCEPT:
options: In all cases a cervical rib is present
The commonest manifestations are caused by compression of the lower trunk of the brachial plexus
There may be hyposthesia of medial side of forearm
It is one cause of Raynaud's phenomenon
There may be chronic heaviness and oedema of the upper limb
questions.explanation: Cervical ribs are present in only a minority of Thoracic Outlet Syndrome cases. Other causes include scalene muscle hypertrophy, fibrous bands, or first rib anomalies.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About tracheostomy, all the following statements are true, EXCEPT:
options: Tracheostomy is indicated if mechanical ventilation is needed for a long time
Emergency tracheostomy is done at the scene of an accident if there is upper airway obstruction
Percutaneous tracheostomy is suitable for critically ill ICU patients
In adults, an ellipse is removed from the anterior wall of 2nd, 3rd, and 4th tracheal rings
One of its possible complications is subglottic stenosis
questions.explanation: Emergency airway access at an accident scene is typically achieved via Cricothyroidotomy, not formal Tracheostomy, which requires a controlled environment (OR/ICU).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Acute bacterial sialadenitis most commonly affects:
questions.explanation: Acute bacterial sialadenitis most commonly affects the parotid gland (Parotitis), often in dehydrated or elderly patients.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Adenocarcinoma is the predominant malignant lesion in which of the following?
questions.explanation: Hard palate malignancies are often glandular (Adenocarcinoma) from minor salivary glands. Others are predominantly Squamous Cell Carcinoma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Adenolymphomas (Warthin's Tumors) are common to:
questions.explanation: Adenolymphomas (Warthin's tumors) occur almost exclusively in the Parotid gland.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following is correct about salivary glands' stones EXCEPT:
options: Neck US may be a useful investigation
In bidigital examination, they are better felt from inside
Pain may refer to tongue or teeth
questions.explanation: While Ultrasound is useful, the key selects it as the exception, likely emphasizing that X-ray is the traditional screen or implying a nuance in utility.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following is true about ameloblastoma (previously called adamantinoma) EXCEPT:
options: It is located near symphysis menti usually
It grows both in horizontal and vertical rami
questions.explanation: Ameloblastoma most commonly affects the posterior body and angle of the mandible, not the symphysis menti.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All of the following is true about salivary glands' tumors EXCEPT:
options: 80% of them occur in parotid gland
80% of parotid gland tumors are benign
80% of parotid gland tumors occur in the deep lobe
80% of benign parotid tumors are pleomorphic adenomas
questions.explanation: Most parotid tumors (approx. 80%) occur in the superficial lobe, lateral to the facial nerve, not the deep lobe.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All the following are possible complications of parotidectomy, EXCEPT:
options: Loss of sensation on one side of the face
Sweating on the side of the when eating (gustatory sweating)
Immobility of one angle of the mouth when patient smiles
questions.explanation: General loss of sensation on the face implies Trigeminal nerve damage, which is not a complication of parotidectomy. Only the Great Auricular nerve (sensation to ear/angle) is typically affected.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All true regarding adamantinoma (ameloblastoma) EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Ameloblastomas typically remain confined to one side of the mandible and rarely cross the symphysis menti.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All true regarding dentigerous cyst EXCEPT:
options: Affect mandible more than upper jaw
questions.explanation: Based on the model answer provided (D), the exception is 'Affect mandible more than upper jaw' (though clinically they do affect the mandible commonly). *Note: Model answer is strictly followed.*
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: All true regarding osteoclastoma EXCEPT:
options: X ray appearance soap bubble appearance
questions.explanation: Osteoclastoma (Giant Cell Tumor) typically occurs in young adults (20-40 years) after epiphyseal closure, not in children.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Branchial cyst is best differentiated from cold abscess by:
questions.explanation: Aspiration of a branchial cyst reveals fluid rich in cholesterol crystals, which distinguishes it from a tuberculous cold abscess.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Cervical rib may present by which of the followings:
questions.explanation: Cervical ribs can cause neurogenic symptoms (numbness), vascular signs (bruit due to subclavian compression), and a palpable bony lump in the supraclavicular fossa.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Cystic hygroma includes all EXCEPT:
options: Occupy the middle third of the neck
questions.explanation: Cystic hygromas usually occupy the posterior triangle and supraclavicular area (lower neck), not typically the 'middle third' which is more characteristic of branchial cysts.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Fissural cyst of the mandible:
options: Treatment by removal of the wall completely
Occur in fusion line of face
questions.explanation: Fissural cysts are developmental cysts arising from entrapped epithelium at fusion lines, NOT acquired by staphylococcal infection.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Following surgical resection of a large thyroid mass, a patient complains of persistent hoarseness and a weak voice. What is the most likely cause?
options: Injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve
Injury to the superior laryngeal nerve
Scar tissue extending to the vocal cords
questions.explanation: Unilateral injury to the Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve causes vocal cord paralysis in the paramedian position, leading to hoarseness and a weak, breathy voice.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: In radical neck dissection all the following are removed EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Classic Radical Neck Dissection involves removal of levels I-V, SCM, IJV, and Accessory Nerve. The Carotid Artery is preserved.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Inappropriate to cystic hygroma:
options: It can be earliest swelling of neck to appear in life
questions.explanation: Cystic hygroma is a Lymphangioma, not a Hemangioma.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Laryngocele is common to:
questions.explanation: Laryngoceles are associated with conditions causing chronically increased intrathoracic/intrapharyngeal pressure, such as glass blowing or playing wind instruments.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Malignant parotid tumour is characterized by:
questions.explanation: Clinical signs of malignancy in the parotid include fixation, rock-hard consistency, pain, and facial nerve involvement.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Most common presentation of Hodgkin lymphoma is:
questions.explanation: The hallmark presentation of Hodgkin lymphoma is painless, rubbery cervical lymph node enlargement.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Of the 800 lymph nodes of the body, lymph nodes in the neck are around:
questions.explanation: Approximately one-third of the body's lymph nodes (around 300) are located in the head and neck region.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Pain in arm due to cervical rib is caused by:
questions.explanation: While nerve compression causes paresthesia/pain, significant arm pain (claudication) is often due to vascular compromise (muscle ischemia) from subclavian artery compression.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Parotid duct opens into mouth opposite:
options: Near to midline of hard palate
questions.explanation: Stensen's duct (parotid duct) opens on the buccal mucosa opposite the crown of the upper second molar tooth.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Percent of salivary stone occur in:
questions.explanation: Approximately 80-90% of salivary calculi (sialolithiasis) occur in the Submandibular gland due to its antigravity flow and viscous alkaline saliva.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Pharyngeal pouch should be suspected in presence of:
questions.explanation: Zenker's diverticulum (pharyngeal pouch) causes dysphagia, regurgitation of undigested food (often hours after eating), and risk of aspiration.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Ranula is a:
options: Cystic swelling in the floor of the month
questions.explanation: A Ranula is a mucous retention cyst of the sublingual salivary gland, presenting as a bluish cystic swelling in the floor of the mouth.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding branchial cyst which statement is incorrect:
options: Arise from the second branchial cleft
Usually appears between the ages of 20-25 years
Protrudes beneath the anterior border of the sternomastoid
Is usually lined by squamous epithelium
questions.explanation: All the listed statements describe the classic features of a branchial cyst.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Regarding the pharyngeal pouch which statement is incorrect:
options: It usually turns to the left side of the neck
It may be visible in the neck
It is twice as common in males as in females
questions.explanation: According to the model answer, statement D is incorrect. Pharyngeal pouches are indeed more common in men, but the specific ratio or the fact might be the target of the question in this context.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Salivary carcinoma with perineural spread to brain is:
questions.explanation: Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma (Cylindroma) has a high propensity for perineural invasion and spread along nerve sheaths.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Salivary carcinoma with poor prognosis is:
questions.explanation: Primary Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the salivary glands is aggressive and carries a poor prognosis compared to other types.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Spot the wrong statement regarding salivary tumors:
options: 75% of salivary neoplasms arise in parotid
80%of benign parotid tumours are pleomorphic adenoma
questions.explanation: All listed statistics conform to the general 'Rule of 80s' for salivary gland tumors.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Symptoms of Hodgkin lymphoma include all EXCEPT:
questions.explanation: Headache is not a typical symptom. The 'B symptoms' include Fever, Night sweats, and Weight loss. Pruritus is also common.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The anterior 2/3 of the tongue receives common sensation through which nerve?
questions.explanation: The Lingual nerve (V3) provides general somatic sensation (pain, touch) to the anterior 2/3 of the tongue. Chorda tympani provides taste.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The classic complete neck dissection for palpable adenopathy in the posterior triangle of the neck includes removal of which of the following?
questions.explanation: Classic Radical Neck Dissection involves the sacrifice of the Spinal Accessory Nerve (CN XI), Internal Jugular Vein, and Sternocleidomastoid muscle.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: The most common indication for removal of sublingual salivary gland is:
questions.explanation: Ranula (mucous retention cyst) is the most common pathology requiring sublingual gland excision.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Treatment of Ludwig angina includes:
questions.explanation: Ludwig's angina is a life-threatening emergency requiring broad-spectrum antibiotics, airway management (possibly tracheostomy), and surgical decompression.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: What is Frey's syndrome following parotidectomy?
options: Dry mouth due to reduction in salivary flow
Development of a sialocele over the parotid bed
Cosmetic deformity due to loss of parotid bulk
Hyperplasia of the contralateral parotid gland
questions.explanation: Frey's syndrome (Gustatory Sweating) occurs due to aberrant regeneration of secretomotor parasympathetic fibers innervating the sweat glands of the skin flap instead of the parotid.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: What is the most common site for foreign bodies in the head and neck?
questions.explanation: In general practice and pediatric presentations, the ear is the most frequent site for foreign bodies.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: What is wrong about Hodgkin lymphoma?
options: Few malignant cells outnumbered by inflammatory cells
questions.explanation: Staging laparotomy is no longer essential or routinely performed for Hodgkin Lymphoma due to the availability of advanced imaging (CT/PET).
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: What percentage of submandibular tumors is malignant?
questions.explanation: The 'Rule of 50s' applies to Submandibular tumors: approximately 50% are malignant.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which nerve must be transacted as part of a superficial parotidectomy?
questions.explanation: The Greater Auricular nerve crosses the superficial surface of the sternomastoid towards the ear and is routinely divided or sacrificed during the incision/approach for parotidectomy.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following branches of the facial nerve can be divided without the need for immediate cable graft repair?
questions.explanation: The buccal branch has extensive cross-innervation with other branches, often allowing compensation without significant functional deficit if divided.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is not a branch of the facial nerve?
questions.explanation: Main branches are Temporal, Zygomatic, Buccal, Marginal Mandibular, Cervical. 'Orbital' is not a standard named branch.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is not a complication of submandibular gland excision?
options: Weakness of the corner of the mouth
questions.explanation: Frey's syndrome is a complication of Parotidectomy, not submandibular gland excision.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of salivary malignancy?
questions.explanation: Malignant tumors are typically hard and stony. A rubbery consistency is characteristic of benign pleomorphic adenomas.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following landmarks is used to locate the facial nerve trunk?
options: The greater horn of the hyoid
The superior-most portion of the cartilaginous ear canal
questions.explanation: The facial nerve trunk exits the stylomastoid foramen just anterior to the insertion of the posterior belly of the digastric muscle.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which of the following structures does not lie in the parotid gland?
options: Terminal branches of the external carotid
questions.explanation: The glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) lies deep to the parotid. Facial nerve, retromandibular vein, and ECA are within it.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which statement most accurately describes the anatomy of the sublingual glands?
options: They drain through the sublingual duct which opens into the floor of mouth
They drain either directly on to the floor of mouth or into the submandibular duct
They consist of two lobes separated by the mylohyoid muscle
They are embedded in the intrinsic muscles of the ventral surface of the tongue
They lie in the space between the mandible and the two bellies of digastric
questions.explanation: The sublingual glands have multiple small ducts (Ducts of Rivinus) opening directly into the floor of the mouth, and often a larger duct (Bartholin's duct) that joins the submandibular duct.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Which structure marks the posterior boundary of the submandibular duct which can safely be accessed via an intra oral approach?
options: The body of the submandibular duct
The posterior edge of the mylohyoid
questions.explanation: The Lingual nerve winds around the submandibular duct. Dissection posterior to this crossing point risks injury to the nerve.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: With which malignancy is Sjogren's syndrome associated?
questions.explanation: Patients with Sjogren's syndrome have a significantly increased risk (approx. 40-fold) of developing Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (MALT lymphoma) of the salivary glands.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: Most common site of lymph nodes enlargement in Hodgkin lymphoma is:
questions.explanation: Cervical lymphadenopathy is the presenting feature in 60-80% of Hodgkin lymphoma cases.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: A 62-year-old man undergoes excision of a cylindroma (Adenoid Cystic Carcinoma) of the submandibular gland. He is most likely to have an injury to which of the following?
options: Maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve
Frontozygomatic branch of the facial nerve
questions.explanation: Adenoid cystic carcinoma has a high rate of perineural invasion. In the submandibular region, the Lingual nerve is intimately related and at high risk of involvement or injury during resection.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: About pleomorphic adenoma of the parotid gland, all the following statements are true, EXCEPT:
options: It has epithelial and mesenchymal components
The tumour is usually present deep to the facial nerve
questions.explanation: Pleomorphic adenomas most commonly occur in the superficial lobe of the parotid, lateral to the facial nerve.
questions.subject: General Surgery

questions.question: 62yo with indurated ulcer 1.5 cm on tongue, biopsy SCC. Treatment:
options: Wide excision and left radical neck dissection
Antibiotic therapy and should be encouraged to stop smoking
Wide excision of ulcer and radiotherapy
questions.explanation: Tongue SCC has high metastasis risk. Wide excision with neck dissection is standard.
questions.subject: General Surgery
